journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Diagnosis of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis in ultrasound using tissue characterization and pixel classification

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Electronics and Computer Engineering, Ngee Ann Polytechnic, Singapore, Singapore
2Department of Biomedical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Malaya, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia
3Global Biomedical Technologies Inc., Roseville, CA, USA
4Biolab, Department of Electronics and Telecommunications, Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy
7Department of Internal Medicine, Diabetology and Nephrology, Medical University of Silesia, Katowice, Poland
8Biomedical Engineering Department, Idaho State University (Affl.), Pocatello, ID, USA

author-notes.corresp: Muthu Rama Krishnan Mookiah, Department of Electronics and Computer Engineering, Ngee Ann Polytechnic, 535 Clementi Road, Singapore 599489, Singapore. Email: mkm2@np.edu.sg

abstract.p: Hashimoto’s thyroiditis is the most common type of inflammation of the thyroid gland, and accurate diagnosis of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis would be helpful to better manage the disease process and predict thyroid failure. Most of the published computer-based techniques that use ultrasound thyroid images for Hashimoto’s thyroiditis diagnosis are limited by lack of procedure standardization because individual investigators use various initial ultrasound settings. This article presents a computer-aided diagnostic technique that uses grayscale features and classifiers to provide a more objective and reproducible classification of normal and Hashimoto’s thyroiditis-affected cases. In this paradigm, we extracted grayscale features based on entropy, Gabor wavelet, moments, image texture, and higher order spectra from the 100 normal and 100 Hashimoto’s thyroiditis-affected ultrasound thyroid images. Significant features were selected using t-test. The resulting feature vectors were used to build the following three classifiers using tenfold stratified cross validation technique: support vector machine, k-nearest neighbor, and radial basis probabilistic neural network. Our results show that a combination of 12 features coupled with support vector machine classifier with the polynomial kernel of order 1 and linear kernel gives the highest accuracy of 80%, sensitivity of 76%, specificity of 84%, and positive predictive value of 83.3% for the detection of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis. The proposed computer-aided diagnostic system uses novel features that have not yet been explored for Hashimoto’s thyroiditis diagnosis. Even though the accuracy is only 80%, the presented preliminary results are encouraging to warrant analysis of more such powerful features on larger databases.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hashimoto’s thyroiditis (HT) is an autoimmune disease characterized by lymphocytic infiltration and disruption of thyroid gland tissue architecture and production of specific autoantibodies against the thyroid. HT is the most common type of inflammation of the thyroid gland1 and the most frequent cause of hypothyroidism.2 Early diagnosis of HT would be advantageous in better monitoring the course of the disease, tailoring treatment protocols, and delaying thyroid failure.

The following are the commonly followed diagnostic criteria of HT: (1) a positive test for thyroid autoantibodies in serum, (2) an elevated serum thyrotropin (thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH)) concentration, and (3) the presence of lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid in histopathologic examination. Other common diagnostic tests are thyroid fine-needle aspiration biopsy and an ultrasound scan. Among these techniques, ultrasound, which is a noninvasive diagnostic test that provides an image of the structure and characteristics of the thyroid gland, is the most commonly used technique.3 It was reported that autoimmune thyroiditis could be successfully excluded on the basis of ultrasound alone in 1962 cases among 2322 cases studied (84%).4 Moreover, ultrasound is affordable, widely available, does not use harmful ionizing radiation, and has relatively shorter acquisition time compared to other modalities like computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

Normal thyroid tissue is characterized by homogeneity and high echogenicity in ultrasound.5 In HT, the destruction of the follicular architecture and lymphocytic infiltration result in decreased echogenicity.6–8 There is evidence that reduced thyroid echogenicity demonstrated by ultrasound is a strong predictor of chronic autoimmune thyroiditis even when this disorder has not been suspected clinically.9 Earlier, this change in echogenicity was evaluated based on a rough visual comparison with the surrounding neck muscular tissue.9 Subsequently, analysis of grayscale histogram was carried out for quantitative measurement of echogenicity decline.7 Other studies too have proposed that computerized grayscale ultrasound gives quantitative determination of thyroid echogenicity10–12 and mean tissue density in autoimmune thyroid diseases.

These computerized methods have the advantages of being more objective. However, they are limited by the fact that there is lack of procedure standardization because individual investigators use various initial ultrasound settings. Echogenic appearance of the thyroid gland varies with the adjustment of the gain. Thus, ultrasound diagnosis of HT is still operator dependent, and defined conditions are necessary to evaluate exact data.13,14 To compensate the attenuation of ultrasound energy as the pulses traverse the different layers of the neck, a corresponding amplification of ultrasound signals by the operator is necessary. Too much amplification may mask a true reduction in thyroid echogenicity, and too little amplification may lead to a false diagnosis of reduced thyroid echogenicity.9 Furthermore, in the end stage of HT, mean tissue density assessment may be misleading because of the presence of a combination of the hyperechoic and hypoechoic signals in the examined zone.15 These operator dependent and echogenic limitations motivated us to develop more objective, noninvasive, and accurate HT diagnosis support systems that use medical image mining techniques.

Image mining uses techniques from statistics and artificial intelligence to determine features that quantitatively characterize the patterns in an image. In this context, these features quantify the textural changes in the ultrasound thyroid images obtained from normal and HT-affected patients. These features can then be used to train supervised learning-based classifiers to relate the extracted features from an image to the corresponding class (normal or HT-affected abnormal).16 The trained classifiers can then be used to predict the class of a new image that was not used for training. The key objective of this work is to develop one such computer-aided diagnosis (CAD)–based paradigm that uses classification techniques to automatically differentiate ultrasound images from normal and HT-affected cases. Thus, the proposed technique will have the following characteristics: (1) it will use thyroid images from the most commonly used, affordable and available, noninvasive, and safe ultrasound modality; (2) the interpretations will be more objective and reproducible due to the use of standard image analysis algorithms; (3) use of this technique will not incur any additional cost because the proposed algorithm can be written into a software application at no extra cost and can be installed in the physician’s computer; and (4) it will act as an adjunct tool that provides a second opinion on the initial diagnosis thereby increasing the confidence of the physician in planning the subsequent treatment evaluation protocol for the patient.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Figure 1 shows the overall block diagram of the proposed CAD system. The thyroid image database is first split into a training set and a test set. In the off-line classification system, the images from the training set are preprocessed, cropped, and grayscale features based on entropy, Gabor wavelet, moments, image texture, and higher order spectra (HOS) are extracted from the cropped image. Significant features are selected from the extracted features using the student’s t-test. The significant features and the ground truth of whether the image is normal or HT-affected are used to train three classifiers: support vector machine (SVM), k-nearest neighbor (KNN), and radial basis probabilistic neural network (RBPNN). The result of training phase is a set of classifier parameters that relate the significant features to the ground truth. In the online system, only the features deemed significant during the off-line training phase are computed from the remaining test images. The classifier training parameters are applied on these features to predict the class of the test image. Once several test images are evaluated in such a way, the predicted class labels are compared with the respective original ground truth class labels of the test images to calculate the classifier performance measures like accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and positive predictive value (PPV). This testing is repeated for all the classifiers. The classifier resulting in the best accuracy is then chosen as the optimal classifier that is to be used in future software implementation of the proposed CAD technique. Detailed explanations of the methods in every block are given in this section.

caption.p: Block diagram of the proposed CAD technique for HT detection. The blocks outside the dotted shaded rectangular box represent the flow in the off-line learning-based system, and the blocks within the dotted box indicate the online real-time test system.

sec.title: Image acquisition and preprocessing
sec.p: Thyroid images were obtained from 68 normal and 82 patients affected by HT (a total of 150 patients). The sonographers manually selected one or two images from each of the patients based on the image quality to increase the database size to 200 images (100 normal and 100 abnormal images). In all patients with HT, the following inclusion criteria were used: (1) age above 18 years; (2) serum positivity for thyroglobulin (TgAb) and/or thyroperoxidase (TPOAb) antibodies and a raised TSH level; (3) serum negativity for TSH receptor antibody (TRAb); (4) absence of nodular thyroid disease; (5) no clinical history of hyperthyroidism; (6) no treatment with drugs known to interfere with thyroid function prior to enrollment; (7) no pregnancy in the 18 months prior to enrollment; (8) no radiotherapy of the neck region; and (9) no clinical history of thyroid operation. The following inclusion criterion was applied in selecting the normal subjects apart from criteria (4) to (9) listed above: normal levels of TPOAb, TgAb, TSH, free thyroxine (f-T4), and TRAb.

All the images were obtained using the ultrasonography machine Logiq 5 (General Electric) with a linear scan head of 10 MHz frequency. The option of harmonic imaging was off. The power of the beam was set to 90%, and the two foci were set at the central part of the lobe. We conducted echogenicity measurements in an absolute scale with no initial manual settings (time gain compensation was off). Figure 2(a)–(c) shows typical images of normal thyroid condition and (d)–(f) shows typical images of thyroid affected by HT. The images were first automatically cropped in order to remove the black frame surrounding the image. We filtered the image by using a vertical and a horizontal gradients. Since the frame border of the image is homogeneous (apart from possible characters placed by the clinicians), the gradients are null in correspondence of the border itself. Hence, we found the first row (from the top of the vertical gradient) and the first column (from the left of the horizontal gradient) that were nonnull and were used to mark the beginning of the ultrasound image region. The last row (the bottom of the vertical gradient) and the rightmost column that were nonnull marked the end of the image. In Figure 2, the red border indicates the normal and abnormal areas in the respective ultrasound images. Figure 3(a) and (c) shows the normal and abnormal thyroid ultrasound images, and Figure 3(b) and (d) shows the corresponding histograms that indicate how the pixels are distributed between two classes. The average HT size is small, around 5–10 mL (mm3), that is, around 13 mm × 15 mm × 35 mm of one thyroid lobe. The normal thyroid is bigger, between 7 and 25 mL (around 16 mm × 18 mm × 45 mm of one thyroid lobe).

caption.p: Ultrasound images of (a)–(c) normal and (d)–(f) abnormal thyroid conditions.
(a) Normal ultrasound thyroid image, (b) histogram of image (a), (c) abnormal ultrasound image, and (d) histogram of image (c).

sec.title: Feature extraction
sec.p: Feature extraction is one of the most important steps in automated CAD systems. Relevant unique signatures from the images will be extracted and treated as features.

In this work, the textural changes in the ultrasound thyroid images due to HT was quantified using entropy, Gabor wavelet, Hu’s invariant moments, fractal dimension (FD), Brownian motion curve, and HOS features. The wavelet transform is used to analyze different frequencies present in the image using different scales. This approach enables analysis of both local and global features present in the image.17 Entropy, Hu’s moments, FD, and Brownian motion measure the uncertainty associated with randomness. HOS is useful in detecting nonlinear coupling, and deviation from Gaussianity and features derived from it can be made invariant to shift, rotation, and amplification. It has high noise immunity,18 and it can quantify the disruption of tissue architecture of the thyroid gland potentially.

sec.title: Entropy
sec.p: Shannon function is based on the concept that information gained from an event is inversely related to its probability of occurrence. Consider the gray-level histogram {hi, i = 0, 1, 2 …Ng−1}, where Ng is the number of distinct gray levels in the image. If n is the total number of pixels in the region, then the normalized histogram of the image is the set {Hi, i = 0, 1, 2 …Ng−1}, where Hi = hi/n. The Shannon entropy19 feature, which is a measure of randomness, can then be defined as

sec.title: Texture features
sec.p: Texture features measure the smoothness, coarseness, and regularity of pixels in an image. We have chosen two commonly used descriptors, namely, FD and Hurst exponent (H) in this work.

sec.title: FD
sec.p: FD is one of the methods to perform texture analysis. The image can be viewed as a 3D object having intensity variation as a covering surface on the 2D spatial plane. Any surface A in Euclidean n-space is self-similar if A is the union of Nr distinct (nonoverlapping) copies of itself scaled up or down by a factor of r. Mathematically, FD is computed22 using the following formula

where FD is the fractal dimension. In this work, we used the modified differential box counting with sequential algorithm23 to calculate FD. The input of this algorithm is the grayscale image where the grid size is in the power of 2 for efficient computation. Maximum and minimum intensities are found in each (2 × 2) box, and two new images are generated from these maximum and minimum intensities. Then, intensity difference between maximum and minimum intensities for each box is calculated, and summation of all differences gives Nr. Furthermore, r = s/M, where M = minimum(R∨C), s denotes scale factor, and R and C denote the number of rows and number of columns, respectively. When the grid size gets doubled, R and C reduce to half of their original value and the above procedure is repeated iteratively until maximum(R∨C) is greater than 2. Linear regression model is then used to fit the line from plot log(N) versus log(1/r) and the slope gives the FD, which gives one feature.

The value of H can be estimated using least-square estimation24 from the Brownian motion curve (f(k) versus log(k)). From the curve, three features were extracted, namely, (1) area under the Brownian motion curve, (2) number of peaks in the curve, and (4) distance between the peaks.

sec.title: HOS features
sec.p:
HOS is a second-order statistics that deals with the mean (m) and variance (
σ
2
). HOS consists of moment and cumulant spectra and can be defined for both deterministic signals and random processes.26–28 Prior to the extraction of HOS-based features, the preprocessed images are first subjected to Radon transform.29

Radon transforms29 have received more attention in image processing recently. It transforms 2D images with lines into a domain of possible line parameters, where each line in the image will give a peak corresponding to the line parameters. Hence, the lines of the images are transformed into the points in the Radon domain. It converts 2D signal into the 1D parallel-beam projections, at various angles,
θ
, and in this work, we have used θ = 1° to get subtle changes. Then, the bispectrum (B(f1,f2)), which is a complex-valued product of three Fourier coefficients of the 1D signal, is evaluated and is given by

where A(f) is the Fourier transform of a segment (or windowed portion) of a single realization of the random signal a(nT), n is an integer index, T is the sampling interval, and E[.] stands for the expectation operation. A*(f1+f2) is the conjugate at frequency (f1+f2). The function exhibits symmetry and is computed in the nonredundant/principal domain region Ω as shown in Figure 4.

caption.p: Principal domain or nonredundant region Ω of computation of the bispectrum for real signals. Frequencies are shown normalized by the Nyquist frequency.

sec.p: The fourth-order moment can be computed using the following formula
The weighted center of bispectrum (WCOB) is given by

where i and j are the frequency bin indices in the nonredundant region Ω. In this work, wcobx and wcoby were computed by substituting the absolute values for each component in the above equations. The following parameters, calculated in this work, are related to the moments of bispectrum. The sum of logarithmic amplitudes of bispectrum H1 is given by
The sum of logarithmic amplitudes of diagonal elements in the bispectrum H2 is given by
The first-order spectral moment of amplitudes of diagonal elements of the bispectrum H3 is

All the above features are defined over a principal domain Ω. All these features were extracted for every 1° of Radon transform from 1° to 180°. Thus, we calculated a total of 1080 (6 × 180) HOS features.

sec.title: Feature selection
sec.p: After the feature extraction step, there were a total of 1139 features. Use of all the features, wherein some of which may be redundant, will cause the problem of curse of dimensionality.30 Therefore, it is a common practice to use feature selection methods to select only unique and significant features that are different for both classes. In this work, the independent student’s t-test31 is used to analyze the statistical significance of the features. The student’s t-test is a form of regression analysis used to assess whether the two classes have different means for each feature. If there is less than 5% chance of getting the observed differences by chance, then a statistically significant difference is reported. Lower “p” values indicate that these features are statistically significant.

sec.title: Data resampling
sec.p: Data resampling refers to the process of selection of images for classifier training and testing. In this work, the k-fold stratified cross validation technique is used for data resampling. Herein, the whole dataset was split into 10 equal parts, each part containing a similar proportion of samples belonging to both classes. During the first fold or iteration, nine parts of the data (training set) were used for classifier development, and the built classifier was evaluated using the remaining one part (test set), that is, among the 200 images, approximately 90 normal and 90 abnormal were used for training and the remaining 10 normal and 10 abnormal were used for testing each time. This procedure was repeated nine more times using a different part as the test set in each case. Average of the accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and PPV was calculated for all 10 trials to obtain the overall performance measures.

sec.title: Classifiers used
sec.p: In this work, we have used SVM, KNN, and RBPNN classifiers to select the best classifier with highest accuracy. These classifiers have nonlinear kernel functions and hence can separate the nonlinear boundaries of the features and yield better classification results. However, among the classifiers used, SVM outperformed the rest. The advantages of SVMs are that they have a simple geometric interpretation and give a sparse solution.32,33 Computational complexity of SVMs does not depend on the dimensionality of the input space and uses structural risk minimization. They are less prone to over-fitting. Unlike conventional classifiers, the SVM approach does not attempt to control model complexity by keeping the number of features small.32,33

The SVM34,35 classifier determines a maximum margin hyperplane between the two classes by using the features from the two classes. The hyperplane is determined in such a way that the distance from this hyperplane to the nearest data points on each side, called the support vectors, is maximal. If the features are not linearly separable using a hyperplane, kernel functions can be employed to make them linearly separable.36 In this work, the kernel functions such as polynomial kernel of orders 1 and the radial basis function (RBF) kernel were used.

In the RBPNN classifier, the distances from the test feature vector to the training feature vectors are determined by the first radial basis layer. The next layer is a competitive layer that adds up the distance vectors for each input classes and produces a vector of probabilities as its output. The compete transfer function in this layer then uses the maximum of these probabilities to determine the class of the test data.37 In the KNN classifier, the feature vector is assigned the class that is the most common among its KNNs.38

sec.title: Performance measures
sec.p: True negative (TN) is the number of normal images identified as normal. True positive (TP) is the number of abnormal images identified as abnormal. False negative (FN) is the number of abnormal images identified as normal and false positive (FP) is the number of normal images identified as abnormal. Sensitivity, which is the probability that a test will produce a positive result when used on abnormal population, is calculated as TP/(TP + FN), and specificity, which is the probability that a test will produce a negative result when used on normal population, is determined as TN/(TN + FP). PPV, which is the probability that the patient is abnormal when restricted to those patients who test positive, is calculated as TP/(TP + FP), and accuracy, which is the ratio of the number of correctly classified samples to the total number of samples, is calculated as (TP + FP)/(TP + FP + TN + FN).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Table 1 presents the mean ± SD of the features that were found to be significant for the dataset used in this work. Using t-test, 12 features were selected out of the 1139 features that had a low p value. The Shannon entropy is higher in the case of the abnormal HT-affected cases indicating the higher randomness in the abnormal images. In the case of Gabor features and some texture features, the abnormal images have registered higher values than the normal images. However, Hu’s invariant moments and HOS features are higher for the normal cases. In the advanced form of HT, hypoechoic areas are mixed with hyperechoic zones due to fibrosis, and the overall echogenicity of the gland may appear ill defined.15 In such cases, it is difficult to diagnose using echogenicity parameter alone. Therefore, in this work, the 12 significant features that capture different pixel information in order to effectively discriminate the abnormal images from the normal ones are selected.

caption.p: Mean ± standard deviation of the various features for normal and abnormal thyroid conditions.

sec.p:
The 12 significant features were used to train three classifiers: SVM, RBPNN, and KNN. Table 2 presents the classification results in terms of the performance measures and the values for TN, FN, TP, and FP. The SVM classifier (with a linear, polynomial order 1 or RBF kernel functions) has two training parameters: cost (C), which controls over-fitting of the model, and sigma (σ), which controls the degree of nonlinearity of the model. The values of these training parameters C and sigma are determined using a “grid search” approach.39 The final SVM parameters are obtained for both datasets: C = 100 and sigma = 0.001. In the RBPNN classifier, all biases in radial basis layer were set to
ln 0 . 5
/ s
, where s is the spread constant of RBPNN. In this work, the maximum accuracy was obtained when s was set to 0.4. In the case of the KNN classifier, the K value varied from 1 to 6. The maximum accuracy (75.5%) was obtained when the K value becomes 2. The distance was computed using Euclidean distance. The majority rule was used for classification, that is, a sample point was assigned to the class that the majority of the KNNs are from. It can be seen from Table 2 that the SVM classifier with the polynomial kernel of order 1 and linear kernel gives the highest accuracy of 80%, sensitivity of 76%, specificity of 84%, and PPV of 83.3%.

fn.p: TN: true negative; FN: false negative; TP: true positive; FP: false positive; A: accuracy; Sn: sensitivity; Sp: specificity; PPV: positive predictive value; SVM: support vector machine; KNN: k-nearest neighbor; RBPNN: radial basis probabilistic neural network; RBF: radial basis function.
All the values are represented in percentage.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Only a few studies have proposed techniques for automated diagnosis of HT. In one study,40 a method was proposed to automatically detect a region of interest using image texture information. A significant difference in average gray levels between the automatically determined regions from normal subjects and patients with HT was reported. Ultrasound images from HT-affected patients were processed by an image processing algorithm that segments the images into regions of homogeneous texture.41 It was found that the gray-level histograms of these regions from HT-affected images were significantly different from that of the normal images. A grayscale quantitative analysis of thyroid echogenicity in the patients affected by HT was carried out to obtain a numerical estimate of the degree of hypoechogenicity associated with the appearance of thyroid dysfunction.12 It was found that in HT patients, the mean of thyroid echogenicity was lower when compared to the normal thyroid. It was also reported that all the HT patients with hypoechogenicity involving more than 68% of thyroid parenchyma are hypothyroid.

In another study,42 a low-dimensional texture feature vector was constructed from a sample of just four pixels that were determined using an optimization procedure. On classifying 37 subjects, 92% accuracy was reported in discriminating chronically inflamed thyroid tissue from normal thyroid gland using this feature vector. However, the study was limited by small dataset and large class overlap. Muzzolini’s spatial features and Haralick’s co-occurrence features were extracted from a test set of 540 sonograms obtained from 18 subjects.43 Sensitivity reached 66.7% to 100% and specificity reached 88.9% to 100% on using as few as one optimal feature among the 129 texture characteristics tested.

This article presents a computer-aided classification framework for the classification of normal subjects and patients affected with HT. Using the selected 12 features in an SVM classifier with the polynomial kernel of order 1 resulted in the highest classification accuracy of 80%, sensitivity of 76%, specificity of 84%, and PPV of 83.3%. The following are the novel contributions of the work:

list-item.p: Development of an automatic, real-time, online CAD-based paradigm for HT-affected abnormal and normal thyroid classification. As soon as the image is input into the software, it is preprocessed, significant features are calculated, and the optimal classifier uses the features and its training parameters to predict the class label. No user interaction or retraining of classifiers is necessary.
Extraction of novel grayscale features for training the supervised learning-based classifiers during the off-line training process.

sec.p: On the limitations front, one could intend to test the technique on a larger database obtained from multiethnic trials to further validate the technique. In a study by Anderson et al.,44 it was concluded that the sonographic features and vascularity of nodular HT are extremely variable and overlap with the findings generally associated with other benign and malignant thyroid nodules. It was also reported that nodular HT occurred with nearly equal frequency when diffuse parenchymal changes were present as when the parenchyma was sonographically normal. These findings indicate that it is difficult to capture the subtle sonographic changes that characterize the images from normal and HT-affected cases. Such a lack of clear sonographic difference between the two classes may be one of the reasons why the features extracted from these images resulted in only an accuracy of 80%. In future, one can intend to explore advanced other texture-based features to improve the classification accuracy. Another limitation is the fact that our results are limited to the use of this particular scanner and its settings. Use of other scanners may result in different numerical values for the selected features, depending on the field of view, dynamic range, and transducer center frequency. This issue can be resolved by using an initial calibration (e.g. using a grayscale phantom).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Accurate and noninvasive CAD-based adjunct tools are necessary to provide a confident second opinion on HT. In this work, the proposed technique used a combination of 12 features extracted from thyroid ultrasound images in an SVM classifier using polynomial order 1 kernel. Our proposed system is able to achieve the highest accuracy of 80%, sensitivity of 76%, and specificity of 84%.

The proposed CAD system uses novel features that have not yet been explored for HT diagnosis. The technique is noninvasive, cost-effective, fast, automatic, and provides a more objective and reproducible classification of normal and HT-affected patients. Even though the accuracy is only 80%, the presented preliminary results are encouraging to warrant analysis of more such powerful features on larger databases.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
